habitat: Grows on trees in mountainous regions; usually a weak parasite to saprophyte. Occurs in clusters on tree trunks and dead branches. General habitat: moist-deciduous to wet evergreen forests (Western Ghats).
shortDescription: An edible jelly fungus, gray-brown and often hairy, commonly used in Asian (especially Chinese) cuisine for its texture; grows in clusters on trees.
edibility: Edible; commonly used in Asian cooking, especially Chinese cuisine; valued for texture in soups and stir-fries.
benefitsOrToxicity: Exhibits anticoagulant effects (should be avoided before surgery or by patients with poor blood clotting). Shows antioxidant and antimicrobial properties; extracts may adsorb glucose and suppress α-amylase, potentially aiding postprandial glycemic control.

identification.cap: Fruit body resupinate or pileate, loosely attached laterally, sometimes with a very short stalk. Sterile surface dark yellowish-brown to dark brown with grayish-brown bands; hairy, silky. Hairs thick-walled up to 0.6 mm long.
identification.gills: Hymenium smooth or wrinkled; pale brown to dark brown to blackish-brown with a whitish bloom.
identification.stem: Usually absent or very short when present.
identification.taste: Mild; primarily valued for texture rather than flavor.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Basidia cylindrical, hyaline, three-septate, 46–60 × 4–5.5 μm with 1–3 lateral sterigmata (sterigmata 9–15 × 1.5–12 μm). Spores hyaline, reniform to allantoid, 13–16 × 4–5.5 μm, guttulate. Hairs thick-walled up to 0.6 mm long.

medicinalProperties: Extracts exhibit glucose adsorption and α-amylase suppression; antioxidant and antimicrobial activity (reported against Candida albicans, Escherichia coli, Enterococcus faecalis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Staphylococcus aureus). Traditionally used in Chinese folk medicine for hemorrhoids and as a stomach tonic. Has anticoagulant properties.
note: Synonym: Hirneola polytricha. Known in Chinese as 云耳 (yún'ěr) and 毛木耳 (máomù'ěr).
